Turns out a side effect of this change is that containers that are marked deleted will still replicate/sync.. which isn't necessarily a bad thing. it means we can do stuff in one of the deleted roots, say with manage-shard-ranges and changes to shards like I am playing with in a followup patch to explore this some more,  and have the changes replicate to the other primaries.

However as you say if we just want a bandand to stop the bleeding until we can get auto shrinking enabled _and_ we can just manually remove existing orphaned shards then yeah. This is cool.

I wonder if we can simplify this whole method down to:

      def is_reclaimable(self, now, reclaim_age):
        if self.is_old_enough_to_reclaim(now, reclaim_age):
            return (self.empty() and 
                    not self.get_shard_ranges() and
                    self.get_db_state() in (UNSHARDED, SHARDED, COLLAPSED))
        return False

Because by deinition _all_ unsharded root container (those that aren't shards) are considered root containers. Also even unsharded containers can return no shard ranges and unsharded containers will come back in the UNSHARDED State.

The caveat however is that in this version a shard could be deemed un-reclaimable if it has shards because it's shrinking or cleaving... but this is ok I think, we want them to finish what they're doing.

Just had a play using Al's compact on the probe test, and in watching what happens, a shrinking shard is marked as deleted, but it's shardrange table (in the shard) still has the acctor in it as active, so we'd need to add self.is_root_container somewhere otherwise shards will probably fail to be cleaned up with the above suggested change.

      def is_reclaimable(self, now, reclaim_age):
        if self.is_old_enough_to_reclaim(now, reclaim_age):
            return (self.empty() and 
                    (not self.get_shard_ranges() or not self.is_root_container()) and
                    self.get_db_state() in (UNSHARDED, SHARDED, COLLAPSED))
        return False

I think that might work, but maybe my boolean-fu is failing me at 5pm :P Maybe breaking it into ifs would be easier to read.
+1 see my comment in sharder.py, the whole 'don't reclaim until all shards are deleted' thing must only apply to root containers.

whatever condition we have here that is additional to is_old_enough_to_reclaim() should be the same as used in sharder.py to gate the warning. So breaking it out to another helper may be useful:

(caveat: I've not run this code, and I'm not sure I like the method name)

  def is_empty_enough_to_reclaim():
      if self.is_root_container():
        if (self.get_shard_ranges() or
                self.get_db_state() == SHARDING):
            return False
      return self.empty():

then is_reclaimable() becomes:

  return (self.is_old_enough_to_reclaim() and
      self.is_empty_enough_to_reclaim())


and over in sharder we can use

  if (is_old_enough_to_reclaim() and not
      self.is_empty_enough_to_reclaim()):
     LOG WARNING

The reason I combined the not get_shard_ranges and the not is root check in my example is because I wanted shards to stop being reclaimed if they too were in the sharding state, as I thought we'd want them to finsish sharding before anything else happens. This just ignores the shards state and will reclaim if they're empty. Now thinking with a fresh brain, I empty check is enough here, because if sharding then it wont be emtpy :) So nice!
might be worth a comment here justifying the self.get_db_state() == SHARDING condition i.e. 'playing it safe, future us may conclude it is not necessary'

IIRC a shrunk, deleted shard may still have undeleted shard ranges (its acceptor and/or possibly other overlapping shards). Deleted shards should always be reclaimable after reclaim age, and we shouldn't emit this warning for shards. So I think we need to add

  and broker.is_root_container()

neutron/agent/linux/interface.py.message:
But if I'm not wrong, the device namespace is set in [1], just after the method fails with "NetworkInterfaceNotFound". Where this device.namespace is set?

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/0a6b9cc39527c13fc663709ae9da3ac033407423/neutron/agent/linux/ip_lib.py#L464
Ok, now I understand and makes sense. Thanks!

Yes, it's set exactly in the place You pointed to. And that set_netns() method is called from the add_device_to_namespace() which is called in L358. So, if for any reason device will be created and then quickly deleted in ovs (what we saw in the failed functional tests many times), it will throw NetworkInterfaceNotFound in https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/0a6b9cc39527c13fc663709ae9da3ac033407423/neutron/agent/linux/ip_lib.py#L465 when device.namespace is already set. Then during the retry, add_device_to_namespace() will look for device already in namespace and will every time raise exception that device is not found there (which is correct as recreated device is in global scope again)

    then check if the api version is new enough
      if yes, proceed
      if not, fail
  otherwise
    if the user is attempting to resize a volume-backed image, fail 

> An "else" clause would also be good here but it is generic and has a lot of cases among which I can't think of a bad one right now but might cause issues later. Eg: if --confirm-reimage option is not passed, everything will go into else.
> This "elif" clause is specific and here we're just dealing with two cases,
> 
> 1) image backed instance
> 2) volume backed instance
> 
> which to me is simple and straightforward. what do you think?

All that will change if you change to an 'else' here is that we will also check if 'image' is None for older API versions and prevent the operation if so. I don't see why we shouldn't do that client side, even if the server would eventually catch the issues for us.

> 
> [1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L1208-L1209
Just remembered the case, we allowed volume backed server rebuild having same old and new image (before mv 2.93) so the else would cause failure in that case which used to work before.

We don't allow reimaging on the API side if MV < 2.93[1] so we just check here for the --confirm-reimage flag.
1) If --confirm-reimage is passed then microversion should be >= 2.93
2) If --confirm-reimage is not passed and microversion is greater than or equal to 2.93, then the instance should be image backed (and not volume backed)

An "else" clause would also be good here but it is generic and has a lot of cases among which I can't think of a bad one right now but might cause issues later. Eg: if --confirm-reimage option is not passed, everything will go into else.
This "elif" clause is specific and here we're just dealing with two cases,

1) image backed instance
2) volume backed instance

which to me is simple and straightforward. what do you think?

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L1208-L1209

cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/dataontap/c.message: On ZAPI it is setting the `enable_tunneling` as False, Why is it tunneling here (tunneling is the True as default) ? It is getting the cluster name, I think it doesn't need to tunnel to a SVM.
Probably forgot to add the parameter `enable_tunneling=False`. I'll change this.
The method will call "send_request" with "wait_on_accepted=True". So, this method will wait to complete the job iteself. But the driver layer is doing the waiter too.

The ONTAP REST API [1] doc says that "A successful request returns a response of 200 synchronously, which indicates that the movement has been successfully queued" - which means that it will not wait for the LUN to be moved but only for the operation to be queued.


[1] https://library.netapp.com/ecmdocs/ECMLP2882307/html/index.html
should it return the job uuid ? The driver layer is waiting for a job and it will log and do the flow based on that.

Since a job uuid is not returned, ONTAP REST API provide a different way to check the LUN movement status. That's why the dest_path is returned instead of the job.

As we discussed, I think the best option here is to modify the driver layer to log the correct messages and have the appropriate variable names.
it should retrieve the job status. the driver is calling passing one object and the REST method here is getting a different one.
ONTAP REST API does not provide a job uuid to get the movement status. Rather than that we must use the movement status available in the LUN endpoint.
The method will call "send_request" with "wait_on_accepted=True". So, this method will wait to complete the job iteself. But the driver layer is doing the waiter too.
same about driver and client different object types

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/48a36c38008f08cbecaa1504f7723ed5d5f3019b/cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/dataontap/client/client_cmode_rest.py#L224

Not really. The response will never be None, even though the response object starts as None, its value is changed right after inside the if or else block. Both blocks will get the returned value of self.connection.invoke_succefully. This function always returns a dictionary.

That's a bit problematic: the user is setting a QoS as "maxBPS", and the REST api is setting the value as "max_iops". Actually, the "maxBPS" should be dropped with REST client and added to the documentation. What we could include is a "maxMBPS" and use the "max_throughput_mbps".

Another approach is keeping the "maxBPS" with REST and convert from BPS -> MPS. Since the value is an integer if maxBPS < 1024*1024 it should be denied. Also, some passed values might not be respected exactly as informed, because of rounding value.

What are the effects of dropping the config with REST:

1. An user may be used to set the maximum as BPS, instead of IOPS. Of course, adding the "MBPS" to rest would add an alternative to him.

2. Pre-existent system: 
  - Users may already have their types with the QoS, it would require change the QoS values from BPS to MPBS in a new QoS. 
  
   - A volume with QoS during extend, migration or revert to snapshot reapply the QoS. So, if the volume is using BPS and we block it with REST, the operation will fail. 
   
 
Wdyt ?

You are correct, this need to be fixed. We chose the approach of keeping the "maxBPS" and, converting BPS to MBPS and rounding the value up when needed. The idea is to avoid the problems with the pre-existent systems and keep the compatibility.

Also, I added a condition in the function _qos_spec_to_api_args to set the field "max_throughput_mbps" in the case MBPS is used.

As we discussed, the idea is the client_api option be used out RestClient scope. Here, it would just call the fallback directly, as:

LOG.debug(f'The {name} call is not supported for REST, falling back to ZAPI.')

# Don't use self.zapi_client to avoid reentrant call to __getattr__()            
zapi_client = object.__getattribute__(self, 'zapi_client')
return getattr(zapi_client, name)

Avoid building the string on the debugger, better to pass as parameter, so it only runs when the debug mode is on:

LOG.debug("The %s call is not supported for RESt, falling back to ZAPI.", name)
this option is useless, because forcing falling back to REST is done by implementing the method here
If a method must be REST only (not fallback to zapi), we just don't add this decorator to it. So, this parameter can be removed.
Ack. We decided to change the approach remove the decorator, so this code is not needed anymore.

During setting the tunneling, the ZAPI checks the boolean and the value saved for the server, it prevents send a request for a server "None":

this hard-coded value should be a config option.

Each retry waits for: interval * (2) ^ (retry- 1)

first: 2 * 2^0 = 2seconds
second: 2 * 2^1 = 4seconds
...
60th: 2 * 2^59 = forever..

It should be changed.
it would be nice to have a LOG.debug with the job state, since this function may affect the debugging process.

Since there is no code catching the retry, when the retry reaches the limit this "NaRetryableError" will be raised and logged with "Job is running". I think it would be better to catch the error and reraise with a more meaningful message.
nit: no need to specify this, default value for dict.get is already None

is there a case possible where the method also doesn't exist in ZAPI? (maybe removal of a method in future), what will be the behavior of this if that happens? I might be wrong but getattr calls hasattr and might cause cyclic calls?

It's not possible to have this case - if a function does not exist in ZAPI today, it's because no operation needs such ZAPI call. In the future, all new features must be implemented using only ONTAP REST API. Hence, it does not make sense to the developer try to call a function that is not implemented in REST API.

About getattr calls, in our tests, we had problems with cyclic calls when the code was calling 'self.zapi_client' directly - I believe this problem will not happen now. This code was based on 'configuration.py' [1].

[1]https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/f97f7ff514971701a8cd606f65ae5b9f06204a50/cinder/volume/configuration.py#L68

The "true" case is a bit greedy.  Also, this doesn't handle capitalization well so FALSE would be treated as True.  The upstream strtobool looks like this:

def strtobool(val):
    """Convert a string representation of truth to true (1) or false (0).
    True values are 'y', 'yes', 't', 'true', 'on', and '1'; false values
    are 'n', 'no', 'f', 'false', 'off', and '0'.  Raises ValueError if
    'val' is anything else.
    """
    val = val.lower()
    if val in ('y', 'yes', 't', 'true', 'on', '1'):
        return 1
    elif val in ('n', 'no', 'f', 'false', 'off', '0'):
        return 0
    else:
        raise ValueError("invalid truth value %r" % (val,))

Great! yes, "thin_provisioning", "dedupe", "compression" are reported as lists - so a backend pool can support an "on" and "off" mode for these capabilities; the right way to determine if the backend supports thin provisioning is to see if "True" is in the list it reports

config_tempest/services/share.py.message:
Instead of getting 

 "pool_capabilities['thin_provisioning'][0]", 

get
 
  any(pool_capabilities['thin_provisioning'])
  
  
This would let you know whether the backend supports thin provisioning at all; since backends can report one of:

 ['True'], ['True', 'False'], ['False']

This is causing a failure in the test jobs against this repository. test jobs here use the LVM driver which doesn't report this at all (meaning, it doesn't support thin_provisioning). Moreover, many drivers in manila are reporting non-list values as well. So perhaps we need to sanitize this like the way manila's scheduler does:

  # drivers can report a list, or a single value or nothing at all 
  thin_provisioning = pool_capabilities.get('thin_provisioning')
  thin_provisioning = ([thin_provisioning] 
                     if not isinstance(thin_provisioning, list)
                     else thin_provisioning)
  capability_thin_provisioning.add(any(thin_provisioning)

nova/cmd/manage.py.message: Thanks for updating. I'm going to ping bauzas tomorrow to take a look at this PS. I think he is the best person to confirm the logic here.

IMHO I think the likely bug in this is that L2606 intended to say "if consumer not in inst_uuids or consumer not in mig_uuids, default to type migration". But it is currently saying "if consumer not in inst_uuids and consumer not in mig_uuids" (De Morgan's Law [1]).

I think this code block is intended to only deal with consumer uuids that are not in the instance or migration lists. It's trying to guess the consumer type of consumers that are not being tracked as "active". If the consumers were in either of those lists, we would already know the consumer type.

So if we adjust that, the logic is:

If the consumer is not in the list of non-deleted instances or the consumer is not in the list of in-progress migrations, first assume it is a migration. Then, if the consumer is not in the list of non-deleted instances, assume it is (was) an instance.

 if (consumer_uuid not in inst_uuids) or (consumer_uuid not in mig_uuids):
     consumer_type = 'migration'
     if consumer_uuid not in inst_uuids:
         consumer_type = 'instance'
     
I might be confused but I don't think what's currently proposed in this patch is equivalent to ^.

Either way, I think it would be a good idea to have bauzas look at this and confirm what he intended the logic to be before changing this.

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Morgan%27s_laws

yes patchset 1 was incorrect patchset 2 is closer but im not sure its correct
i will need to think about this a little more.


for things like evacute i think we currently just use one allcoation for both the source host and dest host.

for cold migrate and live migrate i belive we have 2 seperate allcoations in placment.

i dont think this is right
  if consumer_uuid not in inst_uuids:
    consumer_type = 'instance'
  elif consumer_uuid not in mig_uuids:
    consumer_type = 'migration'
    
i think this is actully what we want including the correct precedence for the condtionals

  if consumer_uuid in mig_uuids:
    consumer_type = 'migration'
  elif consumer_uuid in inst_uuids:
    consumer_type = 'instance'
  else:
   consumer_type = 'migration'

and that can be simplifed too

consumer_type = 'migration'
if consumer_uuid in inst_uuids:
    consumer_type = 'instance'

since we want to assuem that if we dont have an instance that it maps too this is a leaked allocation from a migration that has already been purged form the db.


we likely should accutly use consumer type unknown for this once we actuly start using consumer types properly since we have other bugs related to this but that is out of scope of this.

IMHO the above condition is same as:
```
if consumer_uuid not in inst_uuids:
    consumer_type = 'migration'
elif consumer_uuid not in mig_uuid:
    consumer_type = 'instance'
```    
So as per the logic, (copied from above melaine's comments):
If the consumer is not in the list of non-deleted instances or the consumer is not in the list of in-progress migrations, first assume it is a migration. (we can set consumer_type = 'migration' by default). Then, if consumer is not in the list of non-deleted instances, assume it is (was) an instance. (here we can check condition and set it to 'instance').

```
consumer_type = 'migration'
if consumer_uuid not in inst_uuids:
    consumer_type = 'instance'
```

it only ends up being used for logging today because consumer types had not landed in placment when this code was written

It looks like proliantutils is not ready to receive a create_csr call, it is not implemented in RISOperations or RIBCLOperations. And in RedfishOperations the create_csr method is missing the path parameter, and just writes to a temporary file.

Assuming RedfishOperations.create_csr should take a path and write the csr to that path, this raises a few issues:
- 'path' is documented as a directory, what actual filename is written, and how does the user discover that?
- 'path' is a user provided value which results in writing a file to the controller node, and there is no validation that the destination path is safe. This suggests there needs to be a new [ilo] configuration value like csr_path with a sensible default like /etc/pki/ilo (or /etc/ironic/csr?), and validation added so that create_csr and add_https_certificate calls *must* be constrained to files inside ironic.conf [ilo]csr_path.

I have declared the ilo config in next patchset "[ilo]csr_path". 
create_csr is constrained to [ilo]csr_path. 
User can provide the certificate for Add_https_certificate from anyplace, and code will copy that to [ilo]csr_path and then pass on to proliantutils. 
The reasons:
- both steps are though interlinked but still independent steps and user can do one by himself without ironic also.
- There is no way add_https_certificate can find if user has called create_csr or not.

I will post the patch now and let me know the comments. I tried to address the comments as per my understanding. The patch has been tested thoroughly with proliantutils 2.13.2

Another reason to make the default /var/lib/ironic/ilo_cert is that there is no way the ironic system user will have write permissions to /etc/pki for this call to work
See my comment in ilo.rst about this being a valid URL, but only supporting the file:// protocol for now
I have supported file, http and https urls along with absolute directory path.

glance/async_/flows/_internal_plugins/__.message: Is this remains of your debugging?

IMHO we should use at minimum glance.exceptions.GlanceException (preferably defining actual exception for this) so the except can be explicit. Just raising generic python Exception here forces us to use catch all and prevents us differentiating from exceptions for example raised by the NamedExtensionManager.

Yeah, I used Exception in my trivial example on IRC, but definitely agree it should be something specific, of course.

Also "Plugin for import method %(name)s" would probably be more accurate for what is going on here.

if import_method is not in method_list, won't you get a NameError here?

Also, how does the NamedExtensionManager behave if it can't find the named plugin?  I guess it just logs (default value for warn_on_missing_entrypoint is True) and quietly returns an empty list (since we're only passing a single plugin in the task_list).

No, it returns None, which makes the caller get a TypeError since it expects an extension.

But yeah, seems like there's another bug here too. Although maybe we have already checked it against configured methods by this point so we don't actually see it? Definitely worth fixing and testing that though. It would terrible if users could provide garbage there and create a bunch of dead tasks, threads, and log noise as a result.
I've tried testing this by adding some random value in internal_plugins and noticed that there is no error or warning thrown with wrong plugin value.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_nftables/t.message:
it's actually not really shown in the run output. We'll see the "Empty ruleset" though, which is already a good indication.
I can't come with any better name... ?
well, I did find a better name :).

One key difference of action: accept or action: drop is that it appends the rule instead of insert the rule on top. I'm still in the middle of learning nftables but is that behavior simulated by this change ?

Right - so, in the nft role I've created we can't really order things like that. The reason is: order is maintained by the comment - i.e. "XXX accept foo from bar". The rules are sorted by the comment, so we don't really need to manually set "insert", "append/add".

Also, with the previous tripleo_iptables action, the order was reversed for XYZ reason before being applied - this isn't the case anymore here.

When we add (or remove) a rule, the (unique) `nft' transaction will flush the TRIPLEO_* chains, and append the rules in the wanted order. This ensures we don't have any dangling opening - at least in the TRIPLEO_* chains we maintain with this module.

So far, there was no need to "insert" anything. We can see in the future if a change is needed for that, it's for a follow-up.

Does it answer your question?
Thanks. That makes sense. Maybe we later want to remove usage of insert.
